text:
Recalling that the rise of Hitler in Germany and imposition of the Emergency in India came through normal democratic processes, actor Kamal Haasan has said that a “constant vigil” is required to safeguard the freedom of speech in a democracy.

“Democracy is often touted as the only bastion of freedom of speech. It is a work in progress. Constant vigil is necessary to safeguard it,” Mr. Haasan said at the annual India Conference at Harvard University on Saturday evening.

“It is only through the offices of democracy that Adolf Hitler rose to power. In the Indian political history, the Emergency was promulgated and voices were silenced,” he said. In his keynote address, the Vishwaroopam star, who is part of the reform committee that will recommend changes in the functioning of the Central Board of Film Certification in India, said the freedom of speech should not be taken for granted.

“I have taken the opportunity to put on record here and in India that we can’t take freedom of speech for granted and complacently think that democracy automatically means freedom of speech,” Mr. Haasan said.

He, however, pointed out that he was not criticising the democracy of India and, in fact, was proud of it.

“Not only India, but the world is in transition. The world is going to face new challenges, find new opportunities. We want India not to be complacent, but set world standards,” he said. “I, as an artist, believe that freedom of speech is separate from the ruling political state,” he added. — PTI
title: ‘Constant vigil needed to protect freedom of speech’
